title: Family cycles to Japan for World Cup rugby match to find it’s been cancelled
text:
Linford, Dale and Keith cycled more than 8,000 miles (Picture: SWNS)

Three rugby fans who cycled more than 8,000 miles to Japan have been left gutted after repeatedly missing out on watching England play.

Brothers Dale and Keith House and his son Linford have spent 111 days in the saddle, cycling 8,250 miles across 13 different countries.

They had hoped to watch England play France but the game was cancelled because of Super Typhoon Hagibis.

To add insult to injury, the family from Aylsham, Kent, are now struggling to get tickets to Saturday’s final against South Africa.

Keith, Dale and Linford spent 111 days in the saddle (Picture: SWNS)

The family join another for dinner en-route to Japan (Picture: SWNS)

Keith and Dale on the road to Kokand in Uzbekistan (Picture: SWNS)

The family started their epic journey in June and rode in the 48 degree heat in Kazakhstan and faced a 700-mile detour to avoid a conflict zone in Ukraine.

But their biggest setback was when they arrived in Japan and discovered the match they hoped to see had been cancelled because of the typhoon.

Hagibis pummelled Japan earlier this month and caused widespread flooding and landslides, killing more than 80 people.

Linford, who plays rugby for Kent team Snowdown, recalled: ‘The worst day was probably when we tried to go through the conflict zone in Donetsk.

‘But we got turned away which meant going back to the same town we started in 101 miles away and then a massive 700-mile detour.

‘It was very disheartening and this was quite near the beginning – so it wasn’t a good start.’

The family meet up with villagers as they rode through China (Picture: SWNS)

Dale was stung by a bee on his eye while riding through Ukraine (Picture: SWNS)

It wasn’t just bicycles they rode. Dale, yak riding across China (Picture: SWNS)

The family took the ferry to France and cycled through Belgium, Netherlands, Germany, Poland and Ukraine.

The trio then continued onto Russia, Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan, Tajikistan, Kyrgyzstan and China where they crossed the East China Sea by ferry to Japan.

Thankfully, the family did manage to watch England beat the All Blacks on Saturday.

Linford recalled: ‘A rough time was riding in the 48-degree heat of the Kazakhstan desert against a big headwind.

‘We were struggling to do 8mph and drinking over ten litres of water a day without going for a pee.’

Dale and Linford on their way to the World Cup (Picture: SWNS)

Dale, Linford and Keith at the Taldyk Pass (3615m) in Kyrgyzstan (Picture: SWNS)

Keith at the Oita Stadium for the England v Australia match (Picture: SWNS)

Dale, who quit his job to take on the challenge, said the challenge was far from a ride in the park.

Advertisement

Advertisement

He added: ‘Although it was hard going, we were fortunate not to have any major incidents or injuries.

‘I think the worst pain I suffered was from a bee sting to the face in Ukraine.’

The Houses will be flying home after the rugby world cup finals.

The family, who are experienced long-distance cyclists, have raised almost £7,000 for the Alzheimer’s Society, Fight for Sight, and Slide Away, a charity supporting bereaved families.

Dale added: ‘It has been an incredible journey which none of us will forget and we thank everyone who has sponsored our charities so generously.’
